Extra precautions are usually taken by physiotherapists when they treat female patients, including having a woman chaperone in the room.

LeadPara.Para: Key question tackles professional measures expected, especially when treating female patients
Extra precautions are usually taken by physiotherapists when they treat female patients, including having a woman chaperone in the room.

TailParas.Para: And if clothing has to be removed for treatment, patient consent is required and a gown could be provided, said physiotherapists interviewed by The Straits Times (ST).

The professional conduct demanded of physiotherapists here was put under the spotlight after Luke Manimaran Degarajoo, 43, got 11 months' jail and three strokes of the cane on Wednesday for molesting an 18-year-old during treatment. He was found guilty of molesting her twice after rolling down her underwear and shorts during a massage as her friend waited outside the room with the door half shut, at the Rehab Physio Practice in Delfi Orchard.
There are more than 1,700 registered physiotherapists here.

Mr Joseph Wong, 61, of Orchard Physiotherapy Centre said that when treating a female patient, a woman chaperone, like a nurse or assistant, is usually present. This is especially if the treatment concerns sensitive areas, such as near the breasts or genital areas. "It's also important to explain to the patient what the treatment will include to avoid misunderstandings," he said.

Mr David Aw, who owns Emmanuel Physiotherapy, said that when treating young patients, he usually encourages that a family member sits in as well. Some teens bring a friend along instead, which is " perfectly fine" also. "Essentially, what's important is for the physiotherapist to behave professionally, whether the patient is male or female, old or young," he said.

And while removing clothing may be needed in some cases - for example, in ultrasound scans and manual therapy like massages - the patient's consent still takes precedence, physiotherapist Jonathan Lim, 43, of Physio & Therapy Lodge Group said. "I would first ask them whether they are comfortable doing so."
It's also important to explain to the patient what the treatment will include, to avoid misunderstandings.

MR JOSEPH WONG, 61, a physiotherapist at Orchard Physiotherapy Centre. He said that when treating a female patient, a woman chaperone, like a nurse or therapy assistant, is usually present during the session. This is especially if the treatment concerns sensitive areas, such as near the breasts or genital areas.

In Australia or America, some clinics might get patients to sit in their underwear because it's more open there. But in Singapore, a lot of us work through the clothing - it's not ideal, but we want to protect ourselves and make sure the patient doesn't feel compromised.
MR DAVID AW, who owns Emmanuel Physiotherapy
Clothing may be removed to reduce friction, retain the sensitivity of hands and monitor the reaction of the skin. It is especially common in muscoskeletal physiotherapy.

Mr Aw said that in Singapore, patients are usually provided with a gown if they are required to undress. "In Australia or America, some clinics might get patients to sit in their underwear because it's more open there. But in Singapore, a lot of us work through the clothing - it's not ideal, but we want to protect ourselves and make sure the patient doesn't feel compromised," said the 52-year-old, who has been practising for 30 years.

Former national gymnast Celine Go, 18, said she has not needed to completely undress in a physiotherapy session. In cases where pieces of clothing had to be removed or rolled down, a chaperone was usually invited into the room. "Permission for such actions should always be asked from patients first," she said.

According to the Health Ministry website, physiotherapists are governed by the Allied Health Professions Act. Practitioners must be registered with the Allied Health Professions Council (AHPC) to practise in Singapore. Other allied health professionals include occupational therapists and radiographers.

Physiotherapists are also subject to the AHPC's code of conduct, which includes prohibiting practitioners from engaging in improper relationships or behaviour with patients. The council is able to conduct preliminary investigations into certain types of complaints, such as those that involve improper conduct of an allied health professional. It has the option to take steps such as issuing a warning letter to the professional in question.
